handDesc.p: The plates are written in the "early Telugu-Kannada" script employed in the late grants of the Eastern Cālukyas, unlike all other known Kalyāṇa plates, which are in Nagari.

div.p:
Kauthem’s stanza for the king’s victory is an āryāgīti that does not equate him to a god. The king’s epithet is Akalaṁkacarita, which stands at the beginning of the second hemistich, and the word akalaṁka is echoed shortly afterward, implying that the verse was composed for Vikramāditya V. Nīlgunda, Kallasāmbi have the same stanza except for the epithet Tribhuvanamalla (but retaining the echoed akalaṁka). Miraj, Daulatabad: Jagadekamalla. svasti+. samasta-bhuvana-saṁstūyamāna-mānavya-sagotrāṇāṁ

Kauthem’s verse is also drutavilambita and involves prāsa with aḍamarī°, dviḍ-amarī°, mr̥ḍam ariṣṭa° and neḍamariḥ. Although the name is at the beginning of a quarter, I do wonder if it is actually eḍamari there too, with non-standard sandhi: manasodvahaṁneḍamariḥ was emended by Fleet to manasodvahan neḍamariḥ, but manasodvahann eḍamariḥ may also have been intended. Daulatabad has the same received reading. In Nilgunda, the received spelling is manasodvahanniḍamariḥ, where both Niḍamari and Iḍamari obtain with standard sandhi.
